dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: You know, I think a lot of people assume Donald Trump was the most tweeted-about person this year, but actually, it was Joe Biden.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You know, I think a lot of people assume Donald Trump was the most tweeted-about person this year, but actually, it was Joe Biden.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: However, Trump did take the top spot this week for the most tweeted about person of the year, followed by Biden, while Harris was the most tweeted about woman on the platform.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, really? That's surprising, especially since Trump is so active on the platform himself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, really? That's surprising, especially since Trump is so active on the platform himself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it makes sense—Biden's tweets peaked the week of October 26th, right before the election, when Kamala Harris was declared the victor as his running mate.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it makes sense-Biden's tweets peaked the week of October twenty sixth, right before the election, when Kamala Harris was declared the victor as his running mate.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Google Trends, searches for Biden reached a peak the week of Nov. 1 through Nov. 7, the week the presidential election took place and when the Associated Press called his Oval Office win the following weekend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, that was such a huge moment. And speaking of Twitter trends, election fraud was actually the number one keyword this year, even above coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: No. 1 was election results, beating out coronavirus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, that says a lot about what was on people's minds in 2020. And then you've got stuff like "Covid testing near me" and "WAP" also making the list.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's such a mix of serious and, uh, not-so-serious topics. And Kamala Harris was the most tweeted-about woman this year, which is huge.

artist_script:
HostA: You know, I think a lot of people assume Donald Trump was the most tweeted-about person this year, but actually, it was Joe Biden.
HostB: Oh, really? That’s surprising, especially since Trump is so active on the platform himself.
HostA: Yeah, and it makes sense—Biden’s tweets peaked the week of October 26th, right before the election, when Kamala Harris was declared the victor as his running mate.
HostB: Right, that was such a huge moment. And speaking of Twitter trends, election fraud was actually the number one keyword this year, even above coronavirus.
HostA: Wow, that says a lot about what was on people’s minds in 2020. And then you’ve got stuff like “Covid testing near me” and “WAP” also making the list.
HostB: Yeah, it’s such a mix of serious and, uh, not-so-serious topics. And Kamala Harris was the most tweeted-about woman this year, which is huge.
HostA: Absolutely—she made history. And Elon Musk was up there too, which, like, no surprise there.
HostB: True, he’s always causing a stir. But back to Biden—he also topped Twitter Trends overall for the year.
HostA: Yeah, and then Obama and Trump followed him in the rankings. It’s interesting how social media really reflects the political climate.
HostB: For sure. And outside of politics, Boeing won almost a billion dollars in FCC subsidies for broadband access in urban areas.
HostA: Oh right, $985 million—that’s a massive investment in infrastructure.
HostB: Definitely. And then there were all those BrandVoice articles too, like Japan using robots to fight coronavirus.
HostA: Yeah, 2020 was just packed with big stories, from elections to pandemics to tech innovations.
HostB: It really was a year that had everything, um, both good and bad.
